intro: Haplopappus hirtus subsp. typicus, commonly known as the hairy pappus, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of North America. It is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming habit and is often found in rocky or sandy soils. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences, and its leaves are typically covered in fine, hairy glands. It is adapted to survive in harsh environments with limited water availability. The species is part of the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is known for its ability to thrive in disturbed or degraded habitats.
